page.title: 15Housing 1: East Dean
page.content: There are two main areas of residential housing, namely East Dean and the west part of Meads. The old part of East Dean dates back to the Middle Ages and is situated north of Birling Gap in, as the name suggests, a gap in the Downs. However, the houses north of East Dean road were built in the 1930-50s as a 'dormitory' for people working in Eastbourne and Brighton. The design of these houses has followed the character of the older local buildings. The steeply sloping roofs are covered with old, hand made tiles. The inside walls are constructed in ash framing with rough plastered panels. Fireplaces are built of narrow, old bricks and hall floors are laid with old flagstones. They are family houses for middle class people and so are expensive.
